articles.headline: Along U.S.-Mexico Border, a Torrent of Illicit Cash
articles.snippet: As the U.S. has clamped down on sophisticated money-laundering schemes, drug money is being smuggled the old-fashioned way.
articles.abstract: As the U.S. has clamped down on sophisticated money-laundering schemes, drug money is being smuggled the old-fashioned way.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAREDO, Tex.  The streets of Laredo are awash in money, stacks of grimy bills tainted with cocaine residue, wrapped in plastic and stowed in secret compartments built into the trucks, buses and cars that flow south over the Mexican border daily like a motorized river.
articles.byline: By James C. McKinley Jr. and Marc Lacey

articles.headline: Recession? Teenagers Get It, and Are Cutting Back
articles.snippet: Students understand the economic downturn, and many are cutting back on shopping.
articles.abstract: Students understand the economic downturn, and many are cutting back on shopping.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a year of observing their parents pinch pennies and fret about the economy, the nation’s teenagers may be coming to grips with reality.

articles.headline: Helping Children Find What They Need on the Internet
articles.snippet: Google sponsored research to detect differences in how children and adults search and to identify barriers children face when seeking information.
articles.abstract: Google sponsored research to detect differences in how children and adults search and to identify barriers children face when seeking information.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Benjamin Feshbach was 11 years old, he was given a brainteaser: Which day would the vice president’s birthday fall on the next year?

articles.headline: Direct Selling Flourishes in China
articles.snippet: Companies like Mary Kay Cosmetics and Amway have created hundreds of thousands of jobs in China, mainly among women. But direct selling has its skeptics.
articles.abstract: Companies like Mary Kay Cosmetics and Amway have created hundreds of thousands of jobs in China, mainly among women. But direct selling has its skeptics.
articles.lead_paragraph: HANGZHOU, China  Roughly 28,000 young women crowded into the Dragon Sports Arena here for a three-day gathering in September hosted by Mary Kay Cosmetics.

articles.headline: Earth-Friendly Elements, Mined Destructively
articles.snippet: Some renewable energy technologies rely on a group of elements that mainly come from harmful Chinese mines.
articles.abstract: Some renewable energy technologies rely on a group of elements that mainly come from harmful Chinese mines.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUYUN VILLAGE, China  Some of the greenest technologies of the age, from electric cars to efficient light bulbs to very large wind turbines, are made possible by an unusual group of elements called rare earths. The world’s dependence on these substances is rising fast.

articles.headline: Passengers’ Quick Action Halted Attack
articles.snippet: Despite the billions spent on counterterrorism efforts since 2001, something simpler averted disaster on a Christmas Day flight.
articles.abstract: Despite the billions spent on counterterrorism efforts since 2001, something simpler averted disaster on a Christmas Day flight.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite the billions spent since 2001 on intelligence and counterterrorism programs, sophisticated airport scanners and elaborate watch lists, it was something simpler that averted disaster on a Christmas Day flight to Detroit: alert and courageous passengers and crew members.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: Elite U.S. Force Expanding Hunt in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: Secretive branches of the military’s Special Operations forces have increased counterterrorism missions against some of the most lethal groups.
articles.abstract: Secretive branches of the military’s Special Operations forces have increased counterterrorism missions against some of the most lethal groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGRAM AIR BASE, Afghanistan  Secretive branches of the military’s Special Operations forces have increased counterterrorism missions against some of the most lethal groups in Afghanistan and, because of their success, plan an even bigger expansion next year, according to American commanders.

articles.headline: What Iceberg? Just Glide to the Next Boardroom
articles.snippet: Some ex-directors of financial firms that imploded during the credit crisis seemed to skate away from those boardrooms to serve on boards of other public companies.
articles.abstract: Some ex-directors of financial firms that imploded during the credit crisis seemed to skate away from those boardrooms to serve on boards of other public companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOU might think that board members overseeing businesses that cratered in the credit crisis would be disqualified from serving as directors at other public companies.

articles.headline: Back From the Brink (but Watch Your Step)
articles.snippet: Despite overall improvement in the economy, the top financial stories of 2009 are still unfinished.
articles.abstract: Despite overall improvement in the economy, the top financial stories of 2009 are still unfinished.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNLESS you’re Tiger Woods, 2009 has probably been a heck of a lot better than 2008.

articles.headline: Officials Point to Suspect’s Claim of Qaeda Ties in Yemen
articles.snippet: The Nigerian man charged in a failed attack on a jet told investigators that he had obtained the explosives from an expert in Yemen linked to Al Qaeda. The suspect’s father had warned the U.S. about his son.
articles.abstract: The Nigerian man charged in a failed attack on a jet told investigators that he had obtained the explosives from an expert in Yemen linked to Al Qaeda. The suspect’s father had warned the U.S. about his son.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Federal authorities on Saturday charged a 23-year-old Nigerian man with trying to blow up a Detroit-bound airliner on Christmas Day, and officials said the suspect told them he had obtained explosive chemicals and a syringe that were sewn into his underwear from a bomb expert in Yemen associated with Al Qaeda.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: New Restrictions Quickly Added for Air Passengers
articles.snippet: Tighter security and new in-flight restrictions imposed in the wake of Friday’s attempted attack could complicate air travel.
articles.abstract: Tighter security and new in-flight restrictions imposed in the wake of Friday’s attempted attack could complicate air travel.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the wake of the terrorism attempt Friday on a Northwest Airlines flight, federal officials on Saturday imposed new restrictions on travelers that could lengthen lines at airports and limit the ability of international passengers to move about an airplane.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Liz Robbins

articles.headline: Questions on Why Suspect Wasn’t Stopped
articles.snippet: As criticism mounted that security lapses had led to a brush with disaster, President Obama ordered a review of the two major planks of the aviation security system.
articles.abstract: As criticism mounted that security lapses had led to a brush with disaster, President Obama ordered a review of the two major planks of the aviation security system.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When a prominent Nigerian banker and former government official phoned the American Embassy in Abuja in October with a warning that his son had developed radical views, had disappeared and might have traveled to Yemen, embassy officials did not revoke the young man’s visa to enter the United States, which was good until June 2010.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Police Are Said to Have Killed 10 in Iran Protests
articles.snippet: The police opened fire on protesters, killing at least 10 people, including a nephew of the opposition leader.
articles.abstract: The police opened fire on protesters, killing at least 10 people, including a nephew of the opposition leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Police officers in Iran opened fire into crowds of protesters on Sunday, killing at least 10 people, witnesses and opposition Web sites said, in a day of chaotic street battles that threatened to deepen the country’s civil unrest.
articles.byline: By Robert F. Worth and Nazila Fathi

articles.headline: In Las Vegas, Sports Books in a Pocket
articles.snippet: Devices the size of a smartphone let gamblers wager wirelessly in Nevada casinos, and even make real-time bets as games are played.
articles.abstract: Devices the size of a smartphone let gamblers wager wirelessly in Nevada casinos, and even make real-time bets as games are played.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS  For decades, sports bettors in this city have queued up at sports book windows and handed over cash in exchange for paper tickets formalizing their bets.

articles.headline: Adding Fees and Fences on Media Sites
articles.snippet: Ads alone are proving inadequate, and in the next several weeks, some publications are expected to take the plunge by erecting pay walls.
articles.abstract: Ads alone are proving inadequate, and in the next several weeks, some publications are expected to take the plunge by erecting pay walls.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over more than a decade, consumers became accustomed to the sweet, steady flow of free news, pictures, videos and music on the Internet. Paying was for suckers and old fogeys. Content, like wild horses, wanted to be free.
articles.byline: By Richard Pérez-Peña and Tim Arango

articles.headline: Why Studios Keep Cranking Out TV Remakes, Despite the Flops
articles.snippet: Reprises like “The Fugitive,” “Bionic Woman” and “Melrose Place” have fared poorly, and yet next fall will bring “The Rockford Files,” “Charlie’s Angels” and “Hawaii Five-O.”
articles.abstract: Reprises like “The Fugitive,” “Bionic Woman” and “Melrose Place” have fared poorly, and yet next fall will bring “The Rockford Files,” “Charlie’s Angels” and “Hawaii Five-O.”
articles.lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2000 all the buzz in the television business was about a new drama on CBS on Friday night.

articles.headline: A High-Tech Movie Battle: Which 3-D Glasses Are Best?
articles.snippet: Glasses for 3-D viewing come in throwaway versions as well as in models costing $50 a pair. Can one become the standard?
articles.abstract: Glasses for 3-D viewing come in throwaway versions as well as in models costing $50 a pair. Can one become the standard?
articles.lead_paragraph: While the blue-skinned Na’vi are shooting arrows out of the screen toward the audience in the 3-D movie “Avatar,” another battle is being fought in the theater  over the goofy-looking glasses that moviegoers must wear to see the three-dimensional effects.

articles.headline: U.S. Widens Terror War to Yemen, a Qaeda Bastion
articles.snippet: American officials said Yemen could become Al Qaeda’s next operational and training hub, rivaling the tribal areas of Pakistan.
articles.abstract: American officials said Yemen could become Al Qaeda’s next operational and training hub, rivaling the tribal areas of Pakistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In the midst of two unfinished major wars, the United States has quietly opened a third, largely covert front against Al Qaeda in Yemen.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Robert F. Worth

articles.headline: A Peril in War Zones: Sexual Abuse by Fellow G.I.’s
articles.snippet: The integration of women in the military has forced to the surface issues that commanders rarely confronted before.
articles.abstract: The integration of women in the military has forced to the surface issues that commanders rarely confronted before.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Capt. Margaret H. White began a relationship with a warrant officer while both were training to be deployed to Iraq. By the time they arrived this year at Camp Taji, north of here, she felt what she called “creepy vibes” and tried to break it off.

articles.headline: A Tentative Sparkle Enlivens Holiday Shopping
articles.snippet: This season, retailers controlled inventories and expenses, leading to fewer discounts and better profit margins.
articles.abstract: This season, retailers controlled inventories and expenses, leading to fewer discounts and better profit margins.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s stores appear to have fared better this holiday shopping season than last year, according to early figures reported on Sunday. Major retailing categories had modest sales increases, while others fell slightly but still showed improvement.

articles.headline: Obama Seeks to Reassure U.S. After Bombing Attempt
articles.snippet: President Obama emerged from seclusion to try to quell criticism of the government’s handling of an attempted plane attack as a branch of Al Qaeda claimed responsibility.
articles.abstract: President Obama emerged from seclusion to try to quell criticism of the government’s handling of an attempted plane attack as a branch of Al Qaeda claimed responsibility.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONOLULU  President Obama emerged from Hawaiian seclusion on Monday to reassure the American public and quell gathering criticism as a branch of Al Qaeda claimed responsibility for the thwarted attack on an American passenger jet on Christmas Day.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Scott Shane
